page.title: 18CUSTOMS AND DIALECT
page.content: Many ancient customs are still ob- served. It is thought to bring good luck if a dark man carrying a piece of coal is the "first foot" to enter the house after midnight on New Year's Eve. Pancakes are eaten on Shrove Tuesday and paste eggs, dyed with on- ion skins, coltsfoot, lichen and cloth scraps are jarped (banged together to see whose egg has the strongest shell) and eaten at Easter. At Halloween doors are tied and gates removed and bonfires are lit on November 5th. Whilst a wedding is taking place the church gates are tied and not opened until money is thrown. Christmas is celebrated with carol singing, church services, Cristmas Cake with cheese and wine, Christmas puddings and mince pies. The Weardale dialect is still spoken by older members of the commun- ity.
